Wade won't be overturned, but will be nullified Conway: Kavanaugh should not be seen as tainted Tomi Lahren: Protesting has been ‘cheapened by these man-hating feminists’ MORE brought up her own history of sexual assault Sunday in defending Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I feel very empathetic for victims of sexual assault, sexual harassment and rape,” she said on CNN, and appeared to get emotional briefly. “I’m a victim of sexual assault.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR CNN “State of the Union” host Jake Tapper noted Conway rarely discusses any personal history. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR ADVERTISEMENT NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I’ve just had it,” Conway said. She argued that the ongoing Senate debate about Kavanaugh is not a “meeting of the Me Too movement,” which over the last year has seen multiple women coming forward to accuse men in positions of power in politics, media, and other industries of sexual misconduct. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Let's not compare Harvey Weinstein and Bill Cosby, and a few others, to what's happened here,” she said. “If we're going to have a national conversation, stop judging the victims and perpetrators according to their politics.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Kavanaugh's confirmation vote to the Supreme Court position he was nominated to by President Trump Donald John TrumpUniversity offering course on 'Trumpaganda' Fiancee of missing Saudi journalist appeals to Trump for help Grassley says he wouldn't consider a Supreme Court nomination in 2020 MORE is pending a one-week FBI investigation into allegations that he assaulted at least one woman in the 1980s. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Christine Blasey Ford testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee last week that Kavanaugh held her down, covered her mouth and attempted to remove her clothing without consent while they were both in high school. The FBI is reportedly also investigating at least one other woman's allegations against Kavanaugh. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Conway also said Sunday that Twitter and the media should not “bring Trump into everything," specifically her revelation of her history of sexual assault. Trump has a record of multiple women accusing him of sexual misconduct. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “People on Twitter and elsewhere are saying right now, ‘oh how can she work for Donald Trump?’ I work for President Trump because he’s so good to the women who work for him,” she said. “I don’t want to hear it from anybody.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR --This report was updated on Oct.
